main event: A single light object was observed over Kalamazoo, Michigan for 3-5 minutes on October 24, 1968.
interesting points: The object appeared as a light, size comparable to half the diameter of a dime held at arm's length, changing in color from red to orange and dropping or flaming material.
The object disappeared upward into the clouds or descended over the horizon.
The sighting was reported by a civilian psychologist for the school system, who was on the campus of the University of Western Michigan at the time of the observation.
The weather conditions included cloudy skies, haze, and shifting wind directions at different altitudes.

The investigators concluded the sighting was likely a local phenomenon, possibly burning cinders from a nearby ground fire or a student-made hot air device, and the lack of additional witnesses over a metropolitan area was a paramount factor.
result: Likely a local phenomenon, possibly burning cinders or a student-made hot air device.
sighted object: A single light object, changing in color from red to orange and dropping or flaming material.
witnesses: A civilian psychologist for the school system
